traps.description: You clicked on a suspicious link from an unknown sender claiming to be your bank.
You entered your banking credentials on a fake login page.
You clicked the phishing link without inspecting the sender's email address first.
You correctly identified and reported the phishing email.
You inspected the sender's email address before taking action.

realWorldConsequences: Attackers could steal your bank username and password, gaining full access to your account.
Your account could be emptied within minutes of entering your credentials.
Your personal information could be sold on the dark web and used for identity theft.
Scammers might use your account for money laundering, making you legally liable.
preventionTips: Never click on bank links from email or SMS. Always type the official bank URL manually in your browser.
Check the sender's full email address, not just the display name. Banks use official domains like @sbi.co.in, not @sbbank-secure.com.
Banks and RBI never threaten to block accounts via email. They send official letters or communicate through the app.
Look for urgency language like 'URGENT', '24 hours', 'immediately' ‚Äì these are classic scam tactics.
When in doubt, call your bank's official customer care number (from the back of your card, not from the email).

redFlagHints.clicked-phishing-link: The domain 'sbbank-secure.com' is not the official State Bank domain. Real bank domains are verified and well-known.
redFlagHints.submitted-creds-on-fake-site: Legitimate banks never ask you to enter your full password on unfamiliar websites. They use OTP verification on their official app.
redFlagHints.ignored-sender-and-url: Always hover over links and inspect sender addresses. The actual email address often reveals the scam.
redFlagHints.reported-phishing: Reporting suspicious emails helps protect other users and trains spam filters.
redFlagHints.inspected-sender: Checking the sender address is a crucial first step in identifying phishing attempts.
